description: From Middle English bee, from Old English bēo, from Proto-Germanic *bijō, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰey-.

entries.meaning: A flying insect, of the clade Anthophila within the hymenopteran superfamily Apoidea, known for its organised societies (though only a minority have them), for collecting pollen and (in some species) producing wax and honey.
examples: His face was belymmed as byes had him stounge […].

description: Possibly from dialectal bene, been, bean (“help given by neighbours”), from Middle English been, bene (“neighbourly help, prayer, petition, request, extra service given by a tenant to his lord”), from Old English bēn (“prayer, request, petition, favour, compulsory service”), from Proto-Germanic *bōniz (“prayer, request, supplication”). Thus a variant of obsolete ben (“prayer; petition”) and doublet of boon. Cognate with Danish bøn (“prayer”), Dutch ban (“curse”), German Bann (“ban”). More at ban.

entries.meaning: A contest, especially for spelling; see spelling bee.
A community gathering to share labour, e.g. a sewing bee or a quilting bee.
examples: The cellar  […]  was dug by a bee in a single day.

description: From Middle English beeȝ, bie, bei, begh, beiȝe, bege, beah, bye, from Old English bēah, bēag, from Proto-Germanic *baugaz. Doublet of beag, a learned borrowing.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A ring or torque; a bracelet.
examples: And kyng Arthur gaf her a ryche bee of gold and soo she departed
held that a ‘Nicholaitan is an heretike, like Nicholas, who held that wiues should bee common to all alike.’
Cride out, Now now Sir knight, shew what ye bee,

description: From Middle English [Term?], from Old English be, from Latin be (the name of the letter B).

entries.meaning: The name of the Latin-script letter B.
examples: "The ee-vee-ee-ar-en-oh-ee-ell-blank-bee-ell-oh-ess-ess-oh-em-blank-en-ee-cee-tee-ay-ar is especially dee-ee-ell-eye-cee-eye-oh-you-ess." Our friends thanked the spelling bee for his help and then he buzzed off.

description: Probably from Old English bēah (“ring”). Compare bow.

entries.meaning: (nautical, usually in the plural) Any of the pieces of hard wood bolted to the sides of the bowsprit, to reeve the fore-topmast stays through.
